Parent Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document Description: In the case that an individual arrives at a federally funded hospital with an emergency department and is determined to have an emergency medical condition, the hospital is obligated to provide stabilizing treatment at the hospital and/or transfer of the individual to another medical facility. Guidelines for the transfer of patients is governed under 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd (c). Stabilizing care and/or transfer must be provided by the hospital regardless of patient insurance status.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)

Parent Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document Description: In the event that a hospital offers a patient with an emergency medical condition an option to transfer to another medical facility, but the individual refuses such a transfer, the hospital must take all reasonable steps to confirm written informed consent to refuse this option.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)

Parent Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document Description:
Section c outlines the responsibilities of the hospital at which a patient with an emergency medical condition arrived before that patient may be transferred. According to section (c)(1), a patient must be stabilized before being transferred to another medical facility unless: (A(i) the individual seeking care requests in writing a transfer to a different facility after being informed of the hospital's responsibility to provide care; (ii) a physician certifies that the medical benefits derived from a transfer outweigh the risks to the patient or the fetus of a pregnant person; (iii) in the event a physician is not present, a qualified medical person certifies the transfer as described in (ii) after consultation with a physician. 
The transfer must also be deemed to be appropriate.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)

Parent Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document Description:
Section c outlines the responsibilities of the hospital at which a patient with an emergency medical condition arrived before that patient may be transferred. Paragraph 2 states that an appropriate transfer must meet the following criteria: 
A. The transferring hospital can provide the medical treatment to the individual in a manner that minimizes the risk to an individual, and potentially a fetus' life. 
B. The receiving facility has the capacity and personnel to treat the patient and has agreed to accept the case and provide appropriate care. 
C. The transferring hospital sends all medical records and documents related to the emergency medical condition and patient to the receiving hospital
D. All necessary and appropriate life support measures are utilized during patient transfer
E. Meets any other requirements required by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)

Parent Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document Description: Facilities that have specialized capabilities or facilities may not refuse to accept an appropriate transfer of a patient that requires such specialized treatment so long as the hospital has the capacity to treat the individual.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)

Parent Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document Description: A hospital may not delay appropriate medical screening for emergency medical conditions or treatment for such a condition in order to inquire about the individual's insurance status or intended payment method.

Parent Statute: Targeted liability protections for pandemic and epidemic products and security countermeasures
Document Description: This section outlines the actions that may be taken after the declaration of a Public Health Emergency by the Secretary. After such a declaration, the Secretary may require the manufacture, development, testing, distribution, administration, and use of medical countermeasures (MCM). The Secretary must describe the following in the declaration: (A) threats to health for which the MCM may be used, (B) period of time in which the declaration is in effect, (C) Population(s) for which the administration and/or use of MCM is applied, (D) geographic areas for which the declaration is in effect, and (E) specifications for distributing and obtaining the MCM. Importantly, there is a provision related to the Strategic National Stockpile (SNS), which requires that, if the MCM is included in the Secretary's declaration, the declaration shall include a period when the MCM is administered or used with respect to distribution and/or release from the SNS.

This EO issued by Truman creates a framework for federal disaster relief for the US. The Federal Civil Defense Administrator (now FEMA) is authorized to provide assistance during major disasters, plan and coordinate for such instances, and prepare rules and regulations for engagement. This order also highlights the integral role of state and local authorities, indicating that federal financial contributions must be conditioned upon reasonable state and local expenditures. However, the order states that, in the event of a major disaster for which response cannot be delayed, federal agencies may provide immediate assistance and will be coordinated by FEMA (previously Federal Civil Defense Administrator).

This executive order creates the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), consolidating disparate federal emergency management and response entities under a single agency. The order transfers functions from other departments into FEMA and outlines the roles and responsibilities of the new agency.

The President can change rules for any device emitting electromagnetic radiation, close radio stations, or allow government control over them during a war, public disaster, or national emergency, with fair compensation to owners.

This EO creates the Office of Homeland Security (OHS) and the Homeland Security Council (HSC) to enhance national security coordination. The order states that the function of OHS will be to coordinate executive branch efforts to holistically prepare for and respond to terrorist threats and facilitate cooperation with other agencies and subnational jurisdictions. Additionally, this order states that, in the event of terrorist attacks, the Director of OHS will be the primary coordinator for domestic response efforts.

This EO was created to bolster the US defense to biological attack. The order established requirements to plan and prepare for provision of medical countermeasures (MCMs) to the American citizens in the event of a biological attack. The order requires interagency coordination, cooperation through levels of governance and planning for continuity of operations. Finally, the document mandates the development of a federal rapid response mechanism to dispense MCMs following a deliberate biological event.

This EO establishes the Global Health Security Agenda (GHSA) as a central initiative to the United States' mission of enhancing global capacity to prevent, detect and respond to infectious disease threats. The order states that the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) will coordinate US governmental efforts to implement GHSA, establishes an interagency review council for policy guidance and coordination and requires an annual report be submitted by the council to the President. The order emphasizes the importance of interagency, multi-sectoral and international collaborations.

The TSA Administrator can coordinate all domestic transportation and manage transportation-related duties of nonmilitary federal agencies during a national emergency, but this does not override other agencies' transportation authority.
The U.S. can use, control, or take possession of any part of a public airport on surplus government property during a national emergency declared by the President or Congress.

This PPD broadly directs the government to strengthen security measures across a litany of threats, including public health threats. The directive mandates the development of a national preparedness goal to secure the nation and establishes a National Preparedness System to build the capacity required for achievement of the national preparedness goal. All information regarding progress and system capacity will be included in an annual National Preparedness Report.

This directive outlines measures to implement the National Strategy for Countering Biological Threats. It includes requirements for executive agencies to develop an implementation plan, guidance on submitting budgets for programs and required annual reporting on progress toward strategy implementation. The directive also established an Interagency Policy Committee to oversee and coordinate implementation.

The Secretary of Transportation can regulate public transportation systems' operations, routes, or schedules if they receive certain grants, except for national defense or during a national or regional emergency.

The President can allow designated people to use, sell, or dispose of materials in the National Defense Stockpile for national defense purposes during a war declared by Congress or a national emergency.
The President's authority to modify defense contracts for national defense purposes is valid only during a national emergency declared by Congress or the President and for six months after it ends.

This directive aims to safeguard federally funded research and development from foreign interference. It strengthens disclosure requirements for federally funded awards, establishes research security programs, and implements potential violation penalties.

The President can suspend laws related to the production, transportation, testing, and disposal of chemical and biological warfare agents during a war or national emergency declared by Congress or the President.

The President can use the powers under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to address any major threat from outside the U.S. to national security, foreign policy, or the economy if a national emergency is declared.

Donations of food, clothing, and medicine to relieve suffering are usually exempt from economic embargoes under IEEPA, unless the President decides that these donations would hinder handling the national emergency.
Foreign assets frozen under IEEPA can remain frozen even after the national emergency ends if needed for dealing with claims involving the country or its nationals.

The President can authorize the sale of property involved in legal claims related to national interest during a war or national emergency. The sale must follow a notice period of 30 days published in the Federal Register.

The limit on the number of armed forces personnel assigned to the Selective Service System doesn't apply during a war or national emergency declared by Congress or the President. The System must be ready to operate immediately during a national emergency.

The President can waive some prerequisites and the $50 million cap on direct federal loans for expanding production capacity for national defense under the DPA during a national emergency declared by Congress or the President.

During a national emergency declared by Congress or the President, the President can waive certain conditions to use the DPA to expand production capacity and supply in private industry for national defense purposes.

This EO leverages the Defense Production Act and empowers the Secretary of Homeland Security and Health and Human Services Secretaries to more effectively respond to the COVID-19 pandemic by allowing them to guarantee loans, make purchases, and take other steps to expand domestic production of health and medical resources needed to combat COVID-19. The EO also allows the secretaries to establish voluntary agreements and advisory committees to support these efforts.

This EO empowered the Secretaries of Defense and Homeland Security to activate National Guard and Individual Ready Reserve members for up to two years to support the COVID-19 response efforts. The authority for this order is derived from 10 USC § 121 and § 12302. The order allows for the activation of up to one million members of the Reserve and will be coordinated and commanded by the secretaries of Defense and Homeland Security.
This EO empowered the Secretary (under the Defense Production Act) to ensure the continued operation of meat and poultry processors during the COVID-19 pandemic.

This EO authorized the CEO of the United States International Development Finance Corporation to use Defense Production Act powers to support the domestic production of essential resources in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

This EO was intended to improve rural health and expand telehealth access as a response mechanism to challenges highlighted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The order required the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to develop and innovative payment model for such telehealth visits, and in conjunction with the Secretary of Agriculture, to develop and implement a strategy to improve physical and communications healthcare infrastructure in rural areas within the United States. Finally, HHS was tasked with proposing regulations to extend the measures implemented to increase access to telehealth services during COVID-19 beyond the emergency period.

This EO was empowered the HSS Secretary to combat the hoarding and price gouging of essential medical supplies and equipment during the COVID-19 pandemic. The order requires the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to create a list of essential medical countermeasures and critical inputs and the Secretary of Defense to identify vulnerabilities in the supply chain for such products. The order also focuses on increasing domestic production of critical products by directing agencies involved in product procurement to prioritize domestic production and encourage US based manufacturing of pharmaceuticals. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) was also tasked with streamlining requirements to facilitate and expedite the domestic production of critical inputs to these products.

This EO empowered the Heath and Human Services (HHS) Secretary to prioritize American access to safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines developed or procured by the U.S. government. The order specifically directs the HHS to prioritize access of COVID-19 vaccines developed or procured by the US government for American citizens over other populations. The order requires that vaccines be distributed and administered in an efficient and equitable fashion. After all Americans have access to COVID-19 vaccines, the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) may coordinate with international partners to facilitate international access to COVID-19 vaccines.

This EO established a new coordinated federal response to the COVID-19 pandemic by creating the positions of COVID-19 Response Coordinator and Deputy Coordinator within the Executive Office of the President, tasked with advising the President and coordinating the national response, including addressing disparities in treatment and ensuring timely vaccine distribution.

This EO was aimed at shifting federal environment and public health policy by directing federal agencies to review and address federal regulations and actions taken during the previous four years that conflict with national objectives to improve public health and the environment (amongst other objectives).

This EO mandated a coordinated federal response to COVID-19 by leveraging data and analytics. The Secretary of HHS was specifically tasked with examining the effectiveness and interconnectedness of public health data systems, reviewing the collection of morbidity and mortality data by state and local authorities, and providing recommendations.

This EO established the COVID-19 Pandemic Testing Board, and also empowered the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide technical support and training to state and local health agencies to improve testing capacity for the virus.

This EO enables the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Director of the National Institutes of Health, to develop plans to support new studies for promising COVID-19 treatments, ensure equitable access to treatments, and coordinate with Department of Defense/the Department of Veteran's Affairs to enhance production and distribution of COVID-19 treatments in critical and long-term care facilities.

The EO aimed to enhance the coordination and effectiveness of HIV prevention and care efforts across federal agencies. The order announces the HIV Care Continuum Initiative, which aimed to accelerate the implementation of the National HIV/AIDS Strategy by focusing on access to prophylactic care, testing, and treatment of individuals at risk of, or with active cases of, HIV/AIDS. It also designed an interagency working group on the subject housed in the Department of Health and Human Services.

This EO was designed to create a secure and resilient communication system to be used during national security and emergency situations. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) is tasked with overseeing efforts to reform this system and advise the President on the initiative. The order also create an Executive Committee of NS/EP Communications co-chaired by the Department of Defense (DoD) and Homeland Security (DHS), as well as a Joint Program Office under DHS to support activities related to the committee. DoD is additionally tasked with developing NS/EP communications systems that affect national security and include communications with the President, Vice President or national senior leadership.

This EO expands the government's ability to address COVID-19 under the DPA by empowering various departments to distribute resources and expand production of essential supplies.

This EO creates the position of Coordinator of the COVID-19 Response and Counselor to the President. It aims to ensure a widespread effort to limit the spread of COVID-19 by reducing response disparities and coordinating the distribution of supplies and vaccines.

This EO aims to reverse previous environmental policies and combat climate change by addressing communities disadvantaged by previous actions and emphasizing the use of science as the basis of policy-making. It specifically works to revoke the Keystone XL pipeline and gas leasing from the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

This EO aims to implement the national HIV/AIDS strategy for 2015-2020, building on the initial strategy. It works to coordinate efforts to reduce new HIV infections, increasing access to care and improving treatments for diagnosed individuals. It addresses disparities related to gender, race, and sexual orientation.

Creates special quarantine powers in time of war. Specifically, authorizes SG to apprehend and examine any individual: "believed (1) to be infected with such disease and (2) to be a probable source of infection to members of the armed forces." If an individual is found to be infected, they may be detained for a time and manner that is "reasonably necessary."

Requires HHS to carry out a program to periodically conduct public health surveillance activities relating to a bioterrorism attack or other health emergency to test new and emerging technologies. Must consult with public, nonprofit, and private entities and must report to Congress.

HHS must monitor emerging concerns for at-risk individuals, oversee the implementation of preparedness goals with respect to them, evaluate communication methods, and provide guidance to ensure that State and local health grant recipients take them into account. They must also ensure that the strategic national stockpile takes into account at-risk populations and also curriculum for public health and medical response training.

HHS shall provide guidance and technical assistance to federally-funded health programs and activities, as well as to State and local health departments to better meet the needs of populations served by the above. They may also encourage employees at these health centers to participate in emergency response programs like NDMS and the Volunteer Medical Reserve Corps.

HHS through CDC shall establish a grant program to award State, local, and tribal health departments, as well as academic centers, for surveillance and response to infectious diseases. It authorizes appropriations for this purpose.

CDC may enter into cooperative agreements with health departments or political subdivisions in States and Tribal areas at high risk of vector-borne diseases. The purpose is to increase capacity to "identify, report, prevent, and respond to such diseases and related outbreaks." Authorizes appropriations.
Requires the CDC to expand, modernize and improve public health data systems as they relate to preparedness for public health emergencies.

Establishes the National Vaccine Program to "achieve optimal prevention against adverse reactions to vaccines." This program is responsible for development, safety, licensing, distribution, and evaluation, as well as coordinating government and non-government activities and funding federal agencies. Requires the preparation and implementation of a plan.

Creates up to 20 eligible high-acuity trauma centers to enable military trauma teams to provide trauma and related acute care on a full-time basis. Includes grant funding. When there is a public health emergency, the grant recipient shall agree to allow their providers to be deployed for military operations, for training, or for response to a mass casualty event and be deployed by the Secretary of Defense in response to a public health emergency.

Revises Medicare Advantage (Part C) and Part D (prescription) plans to implement special requirements during disasters or public emergencies. During times of emergency or disaster, MA plans must cover services provided by non-contracted providers and waive gatekeeper referral requirements. The rule clarifies that MA organizations must comply with these requirements for the entire time that there is disruption to health care access.
File: Medicare Program - Policy and Regulatory Revisions in Response to the COVID–19 Public Health Emergency

Document Description: Modifies Medicare payment rules for COVID-19 in order to assist health Medicare providers in applying "innovated uses of technology and capacity" that "might... be effective in the efforts to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on Medicare beneficiaries." Specifically, the rule allows Telehealth on a greater basis; alters the payment policies for independent laboratories; and expanding the locations to which Medicare covers ambulance transports under Medicare Part B. The rule also amends Medicaid home health regulations to allow licensed practitioners to order home health services for the public health emergency. Notably, the rule does not  modify arrangements to give hospitals broader flexibilities to provide hospital services outside of the hospital.
File: Medicare and Medicaid Programs; Policy and Regulatory Revisions in Response to the COVID–19 Public Health Emergency

This directive outlines US national policy for managing scientific, technological, and engineering information derived from federally-funded research at various institutions. "Fundamental research", as defined by this directive, is basic and broadly applicable scientific research. This directive emphasizes that such fundamental research should remain unrestricted, unless there are national security concerns that require it to be classified. Research projects should be reviewed for classification before federal grants are awarded.

This directive outlines the National Strategy for Public Health and Medical Preparedness in the US, aiming to protect public health during disasters. It defines key terms, provides background on the US healthcare system, and establishes preparedness policies. It focuses on biosurveillance, countermeasure distribution, mass casualty care, and community resilience. It also emphasizes the need for coordination between different levels of government.

This directive explains the strategy for developing medical countermeasures to weapons of mass destruction. It recognizes the importance of CBRN threats, and establishes a coordinated framework for research and development efforts. It also calls for an interagency committee to advise the coordination and establishment of medical countermeasures.

This directive establishes national policy aimed at safeguarding US agriculture and food system from terrorist attacks, disasters, and other emergencies. It recognizes the presence of disease, pests, and harmful agents, and looks towards protection of these natural or introduced agents. This directive outlines infrastructure, surveillance, and robust screening and inspection procedures through a multiagency effort.

This directive establishes the framework for identifying and protecting critical infrastructure in the US from terrorist attacks. It recognizes physical and cyber attacks and emphasizes the importance of security, requiring federal departments to submit plans for specific critical infrastructure they operate.

This directive directs Homeland Security to develop a National Incident Management System to coordinate efforts between all levels of government during domestic incidents. It mandates that agencies adopt NIMS and emphasizes its importance in various emergencies.

This directive emphasizes the need for measures to prevent acquisition of WMD by adversary parties, integrating counterproliferation, nonproliferation, and consequence management. It emphasizes intelligence collection, research and development, multilateral cooperation, and targeted strategies as part of this effort.

This directive is aimed at strengthening US infrastructure by protecting services and systems that fight against physical and cyber threats. It improves coordination between different levels of government, and identified key infrastructure sectors. It also works to improve information exchange and update the NIPP.

This directive builds on HSPD-8, and includes an implementation plan, a national preparedness goal, and national planning frameworks to protect the nation against terrorist acts, natural disasters, and other incidents.

This directive was issued to ensure the implementation of the National Strategy for Countering Biological Threats. It gives the executive branch 180 days to develop initial implementation plans, provides budget guidance, establishes an interagency policy committee for oversight, and mandates yearly progress reports.

This directive established comprehensive national policy for biodefense, including threat awareness, surveillance, and protection to biological threats. It emphasizes the need for action against bioterrorism across various federal departments and agencies.

This directive was establish to enhance preparedness against CBRN threats. HHS is tasked with leading medical countermeasures, and an intelligence committee is established.
